basic.title: Primary objective
basic.description: What is the primary purpose of script metrics?

options.text: To create visual presentations on projects for clients
options.outcome: While metrics may be shared with clients, this is not their primary purpose

options.text: To gauge project progress and inform report writing
options.outcome: Correct! - Metrics are used to track progress and help with daily reporting

options.text: To track employee performance to match individuals with specific projects
options.outcome: Metrics are about project progress, not individual performance

options.text: To gauge project progress and determine resources required to complete the testing activites
options.outcome: This is true but incomplete as it misses the reporting aspect.

basic.title: Environment Tables
basic.description: Where should you add new rows to environment tables?

options.text: At the very bottom of the table
options.outcome: Adding rows at the bottom can break formulas.

options.text: Within the existing table, above the final row
options.outcome: Correct! - This ensures formulas remain intact and metrics update properly.

options.text: In a new separate table
options.outcome: This would not maintain connection with existing metrics.

options.text: Above the table header
options.outcome: While this keeps data within the table, it's not the optimal location.

basic.title: Metrics Pie Chart Labels
basic.description: What causes missing pie chart labels in the Metrics tab?

options.text: Software bugs raised in any of the test scripts
options.outcome: Missing labels are usually due to chart size or data arrangement

options.text: Corrupted data within the test script
options.outcome: This is not typically the cause of missing labels.

options.text: Chart size and data arrangement
options.outcome: Correct! - Labels may be missing due to chart size or how data is arranged in the table.

options.text: Chart size in relation to the rest of the metrics features on the tab
options.outcome: While chart size is a factor, data arrangement also matters

basic.title: Environment Rows
basic.description: How should you handle empty environment rows?

options.text: Delete the environment rows completely
options.outcome: Deleting rows can break formulas.

options.text: Copy formulas from existing rows and update environment details
options.outcome: Correct! - This maintains formula integrity while allowing new environment details.

options.text: Hide the environment rows within the environment checks tab
options.outcome: Hiding rows doesn't properly address the issue as metrics can still be picked up from hidden rows.

options.text: Keep original formulas for different environment rows and clear content
options.outcome: While maintaining formulas is good, they need to be properly copied to assign different rows.

basic.title: #REF! Errors
basic.description: What causes #REF! errors in the Session Totals table?

options.text: Insufficient lines for all dates in the sessions totals table
options.outcome: Correct! - The error appears when there aren't enough lines for all testing dates.

options.text: Corrupted data within the spreadsheet
options.outcome: This is rarely the cause of #REF! errors in this context.

options.text: Wrong date format inserted into the sessions totals table
options.outcome: Date formatting is not the cause of #REF! errors.

options.text: Too many dates entered within the sessions total table
options.outcome: While related to dates, the issue it's specifically related line availability.

basic.title: Environment Metrics
basic.description: If environment metrics do not reflect the actual number of environments, what should you check first?

options.text: Check that new rows were added within the existing table and have the correct formulas
options.outcome: Correct! first ensure that new rows in the table are always added within the existing table and copy formulas from existing rows.

options.text: Verify that Microsoft Excel is updated to the latest version
options.outcome: First you must ensure that new rows in the table are always added within the existing table and that formulas are copied from existing rows.

options.text: Delete and recreate the entire environment checks tab
options.outcome: Deleting and recreating the tab is not advised as it would be time consuming.

options.text: Restart Excel to refresh all formulas automatically
options.outcome: First you should double click the cell in the data table with the incorrect figure and ensure that the dotted lines displayed over the environment table encompass all rows containing environments.

basic.title: Compatibility Environments Completed
basic.description: What influences the Compatibility Environments Complete figure in the Environment Checks tab?

options.text: The number of environments with 'Complete' in the status column
options.outcome: There is no status column within the Compatibility Environments tab.

options.text: The total number of browsers tested across all environments
options.outcome: The figure calculated based on browsers tested.

options.text: The count of compatibility environments that have Yes in the Checked? column
options.outcome: Correct! The Compatibility Environments Complete figure counts how many compatibility environments have Yes in the Checked? column.

options.text: Environments marked as Complete and verified by a second tester
options.outcome: There is no column for complete and a second tester is not required to verify the tests.

basic.title: New Metrics Table Rows
basic.description: When a formula in the metrics table doesn't count a newly added environment row, what troubleshooting step should you take?

options.text: Restart Excel to refresh all formulas automatically
options.outcome: First you should double click the cell in the data table with the incorrect figure and ensure that the dotted lines displayed over the environment table encompass all rows containing environments.

options.text: Add a new row to the metrics table to account for the additional environment
options.outcome: Adding new rows wont address the issue as new rows already aren't being calculated.

options.text: Double click the cell with the incorrect figure to check if the formula encompasses all rows
options.outcome: Correct! The first port of call should be to double click the cell in the data table with the incorrect figure and ensure that the dotted lines displayed over the environment table encompass all rows containing environments.

options.text: Contact your manager immediately to report the broken formula
options.outcome: The problem should be addressed first by the tester, If the count is still incorrect a colleague can be contacted.

basic.title: Formula Editing
basic.description: When editing formulas in a newly copied Environment Checks table, what is the key modification required?

options.text: Point the formulas to the equivalent cells in the newly created tab
options.outcome: Correct! The formula in each cell of the new table that's pointing to the Environment Checks tab should be edited to instead point to the equivalent cell in the newly created tab.

options.text: Change the formula to use absolute cell references instead of relative references
options.outcome: Changing cell references to absolute doesn't correct where the formula should be pointed to.

options.text: Remove all existing formulas and create simplified versions.
options.outcome: Removing and simplifying formulas is not recommended as this could affect formula and test result accurracy.

options.text: Add error handling functions to each formula.
options.outcome: Adding error handling functions doesn't correct where the formula should be pointed to.

basic.title: Environment Count
basic.description: Why might an environment not be counted in the 'Compatibility Environments Complete' figure despite correct cell population and 'Primary No' checked?

options.text: The formula in the cell showing the figure isn't encompassing all environment rows
options.outcome: Correct! by double clicking the cell showing the incorrect figure, you can see if the formula is not encompassing the newly added environment row.

options.text: The environment is marked as a primary environment rather than a compatibility environment
options.outcome: The question stated that the 'Primary No' column had been checked.

options.text: The environment was added after the initial script was created
options.outcome: When an environment is added shouldn't have a bearing on environment count.

options.text: The count automatically updates only at the end of each day
options.outcome: This is not the case, environments should be counted when added to the table and formulas are correctly checked.

intermediate.title: Environment Check Tabs
intermediate.description: How should you handle multiple Environment Checks tabs?

options.text: Create new independent metrics for each environment tab
options.outcome: This would not maintain proper tracking across tabs.

options.text: Copy and update existing table with new tab references
options.outcome: Correct! - This maintains consistency while incorporating new data.

options.text: Merge all environment data into one tab
options.outcome: This would make tracking different sessions difficult

options.text: Add new columns to existing tables within the environment check tab
options.outcome: While this maintains data connection, it's not the optimal solution

intermediate.title: Compatibility Environments Completed
intermediate.description: What affects the Compatibility Environments Complete figure?

options.text: The primary column and environment count within the environments table
options.outcome: While primary column is important, the checked field is also required to report accurate metrics.

options.text: The primary column within the environments table
options.outcome: Multiple columns affect this figure and the 'Checked' column is also taken into consideration.

options.text: The 'Checked' column within the environments table
options.outcome: This alone doesn't determine compatibility status and the primary column is also taken into consideration.

options.text: Both primary and 'Checked' columns within the environments table
options.outcome: Correct! - Both columns together determine the completion status.

intermediate.title: Environment Lists
intermediate.description: How should you modify environment lists that have multiple tickets?

options.text: Update each list individually to reflect the specific related tickets
options.outcome: This is inefficient and prone to inconsistency.

options.text: Update the environment list tab and remove excess rows
options.outcome: Correct! - This ensures consistent updates across all linked tickets.

options.text: Create new environment lists across multiple tabs
options.outcome: This breaks the connection with existing metrics.

options.text: Update the main environments list tab only
options.outcome: While updating the main tab is important, excess rows still need handling.

intermediate.title: New Row Formulas
intermediate.description: What should you do when formulas don't encompass new rows?

options.text: Extend the formula manually for each affected metric
options.outcome: While this works, double-clicking is more efficient.

options.text: Copy a formula from another sheet
options.outcome: This appoach not match the specific needs of your sheet.

options.text: Create new formulas for the affected metrics
options.outcome: Creating new formulas may lead to inconsistencies

options.text: Double-click and update cell ranges for the affected rows
options.outcome: Correct! - This allows proper adjustment of formula ranges.

intermediate.title: Environment Coverage
intermediate.description: How should you handle environment-specific coverage?

options.text: Create separate sheets for specific environment testing
options.outcome: This creates unnecessary complexity within the test script.

options.text: Combine global and specific environments as needed
options.outcome: Correct! - This allows flexibility while maintaining consistency.

options.text: Use only global environments within the test script
options.outcome: This doesn't account for ticket or environment specific needs

options.text: Use specific environments only
options.outcome: While this works for some projects, it's not flexible enough and the exact environment testing may not be achievable

advanced.title: Duplicated Environment Checks
advanced.description: When updating duplicated environment checks tabs, what's crucial?

options.text: Update all cell references within the environment checks tab
options.outcome: Multiple aspects need attention rather than just this one area, including formula accuracy.

options.text: Update all references and verify formula accuracy
options.outcome: Correct! - This ensures complete and accurate metric tracking

options.text: Copy all formulas exactly for the duplicated environments checks tab
options.outcome: Formula will need adjustment for the new context on the new tab

options.text: Update table structure within duplicated environments checks tab
options.outcome: While structure matters, formula updates are also crucial

advanced.title: Environment Table Metrics
advanced.description: How should you handle complex environment table metrics?

options.text: Simplify the metrics to return the expected outcome
options.outcome: Simplifying metrics could lose important tracking details.

options.text: Use basic counting for the metrics table only
options.outcome: This wouldn't capture all necessary metrics.

options.text: Verify all formula chains and dependencies
options.outcome: Correct! - This ensures accurate tracking across all dependencies

options.text: Check individual formulas that relate to the environment table
options.outcome: While important, it misses the broader dependencies like formula chains

advanced.title: Cross Tab Metrics
advanced.description: What's the correct approach for updating cross-tab metrics?

options.text: Maintain formula relationships while updating references
options.outcome: Correct! - This preserves metric integrity across tabs

options.text: Update each tab independently across the test script tabs
options.outcome: This breaks cross-tab relationships.

options.text: Update the primary metrics across the test script tabs
options.outcome: While important, secondary metrics also need attention for full reporting details.

options.text: Create new metrics to reflect the current testing references
options.outcome: This approach can lose historical tracking.

advanced.title: Un-displayed Metrics
advanced.description: How should you handle metric discrepancies across multiple tabs?

options.text: Check individual tab metrics throughout the test script
options.outcome: While important, cross-tab relationships are also taken into consideration.

options.text: Determine an average from the discrepancies to enter into the metrics tables
options.outcome: This doesn't address the root cause of the metrics issues across the tabs within the test script.

options.text: Use the highest values returned from the tabs within the test script
options.outcome: This could hide actual issues and actual metrics need to be reported.

options.text: Trace formula chains and verify all connections
options.outcome: Correct! - This identifies and resolves the source of discrepancies.

advanced.title: Metrics Updates
advanced.description: What's the best approach for maintaining metric integrity during major updates?

options.text: Start with fresh metrics when major updates to the test script are required
options.outcome: This approach can lose valuable historical data.

options.text: Copy existing metrics from across the test script
options.outcome: This could potentially copy any existing issues within the metrics.

options.text: Verify all dependencies and update systematically
options.outcome: Correct! - This maintains accuracy while allowing updates.

options.text: Update primary metrics across the test script
options.outcome: While a good start, more comprehensive attention is required to cover all metrics.
